Award.AbstractNarration:
This project is an empirical study of the use of judicial mediation in the Chinese legal system today. Judicial mediation has become increasingly prevalent in the past decade in China. Judicial mediation has become a model for resolving not just legal disputes, but broader, extralegal disputes. About the same time as judicial mediation returned to prominence in courts, China's party-state has begun to develop and push for the idea of 'grand mediation' as a mechanism for redressing administrative and social disputes. This project will analyze mediation in circumstances likely to occur in daily life, such as personal injury or family problems. In other contexts, the question has arisen whether mediation leads to outcomes consistent with legal rules. Therefore, it will contribute to understanding of the development and implementation of the rule of law. How does the rule of law develop? What relationship does its development have to changes in processes on the ground in China?

The project will rely on observation to study how mediation is carried out in several base-level courts in different parts of China. Researchers will observe how judges interact with litigants and persuade them to settle, and will also interview judges. The project will also analyze why some litigants agree to negotiate to a settlement and others insist on adjudication.

The study promises to get an in-depth, firsthand look at this practice central to Chinese civil justice. How should one evaluate the rise of mediation in China? Is it a form of constructive and less adversarial justice? Or is it a threat to the integrity of adjudication and thereby the development of the rule of law in China? They will shed light on how Chinese-style mediation is similar to or different from the communal or court-based mediation commonly found in the Anglo-American system. The widespread acknowledgment of the importance of the rule of law in China makes this project especially important.

The project has substantial broader impacts because the question of how the rule of law develops is important to policymakers and the development of transnational business. In addition, the project will contribute to training students in an area of profound importance.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project studies how and how often mediation is practiced in Chinese grassroots courts. Judicial mediation, or court-related mediation, refers to mediation promoted by judges before or after, and sometimes in parallel with the trial process. Our data include interviews with Chinese frontline judges and participant observations of trials inside the courtrooms in both coastal and inland China. Our study suggests that though mediation in theory plays only a complementary role; it has become the predominant mode of judicial activities in many courts. Judges prefer mediation over adjudication for fear that their rulings might backfire – that is, if their rulings lead to appeals, petitions and complaints, and in some cases protests. These consequences in turn have adverse effects on the performance appraisal of the judges. Because of this shared concern, Chinese judges often actively broker mediation settlement. 

Specifically, we also identify the following findings. First, mediation happens at every stage of the trial process in China – pre-trial, trial, and post-trial. Its ubiquity is likely to compromise the authority as well as the sense of finality of a trial. There is no bright line separating the processes and adjudication and mediation in China.

Second, in-trial mediation is rarely successful. Judges often resort to post-trial meetings, sometimes quite lengthy and protracted, with litigants to hammer out settlement deals. Chinese judges actively facilitate mediation. They play a bigger role than simply a spectator or an umpire. Yet, the actual work of mediation often happens behind closed doors. It is not an open process.

Third, because of the protracted nature of mediation, it is time-consuming and undermines the sense of finality of the trial process. Some cases drag on because judges much prefer to get a settlement deal done than to adjudicate.

Fourth, courts that are institutionally stronger put less emphasis on mediation. Mediation is a risk-aversion mechanism. Hence, weaker courts put a greater premium on mediation as a means to avoid adjudication. Other things being equal, bigger urban courts with a more developed institutional judicial culture prefer to adjudicate. Their judges are also more professionally qualified to use the law to adjudicate. Though mediation is practiced in all grassroots courts, it is in rural inland courts that one sees the highest rate of mediation, so much so that mediation has become the dominant process.

Fifth, judicial mediation is not only prominently used in the civil justice system. It is also similarly used in the criminal justice system. The process is known as criminal reconciliation. It is applied in minor criminal cases such as traffic-related crimes and personal assault. The project also collected data on the use of mediation/reconciliation in the criminal side of the system and how the process affects the implementation of justice in China. The motives for courts to promote criminal reconciliation are similar. Frontline judges believe reconciliation is a foolproof process against petitions and appeals. If a victim agrees to a negotiated deal that offers her some monetary compensation in exchange for lighter sentencing or suspended sentence for the defendant, it is much less likely for the victim to petition or appeal to the higher courts and other government bureaus. Yet, allowing the use of money to buy out jail time also raises concerns about class inequalities in the Chinese criminal justice system.
